turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: Friends.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You mean, all the friends he has?

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: There has only been one case, and there was only one friend in that case.
I don't know how far the Court would take that principle, but that's what they've said, parents, family, and friends, and, of course, lawyers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now you are talking about the juvenile?

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: No, I am back to the adult, in this case, under 16(A), this statute, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even an adult--

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: Prosecuted under--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --defines offenses covered by this statute?

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: --That's correct, in one of these cases.
Indeed, that was a statute--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So there's a minimum, in any event, number of people, the jury, the judge, counsel, both sides, the accused, and his father, mother, brothers, sisters, and friends, whatever that means.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: --And friends.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And court officials.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: And court officials.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could the court under your theory of the case impose an order on them that they could not speak of the proceedings until after the verdict?

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: Well, but even... I don't believe that we need to reach that question.
I think it raises--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, maybe we don't need to.
I am just interested in your position.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: --Well, it raises extraordinarily troublesome problems, I would suggest, because it is a kind of prior restraint, and in order to exercise... really what it boils down to again is the kind of problem we are talking about with respect to imposing that kind of a restraint on the press.
In order to exercise his public trial guarantee in some form, those members of the public whom the defendant has attend or who do attend have to consent to the imposition of a prior restraint.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could I ask you just one more... I suppose if you prevailed in this you would certainly request to get into the videotaped deposition type of hearings.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: Not necessarily, because--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know not necessarily, but what is the probability?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you needn't answer that if you don't want to.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: --No, I will be happy to tell you why I think those are different, because what we are asserting here is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if they differ, would you think it is probable you would try to get into those, too, or not?
That's my question.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: --Into the videotaped depositions?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: I would think that we would not try to get into those, so long as the results of those were going to be available when the case came on for trial, and we could see what the jury could see.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then, why wouldn't you be satisfied with a transcript of the entire trial after the verdict comes in?

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: Because the transcript only captures, I suggest to you, about 70 percent of the evidence that the victim--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, not only that, it is not instantaneous.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: --And it's not instantaneous.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that when you get that, it is not news, it is history.

turn.speaker: james_f_mchugh_iii
turn.label: Mr. James F. McHugh, III
turn.text: Well, it's not news, and it's history, and it's not all there, Mr. Justice.
We don't see the demeanor of the witness.
We don't see the kinds of things that historically have been used by juries to judge who is telling the truth.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at ten o clock.
